content.html:
The digit sequence that marks each note I publish here is the date and time that I wrote the note, expressed in the format: yy.z.B where:

yy
the year in two-digit format

z
the day of the year, starting from 0

B
the .beat

I developed the use of this format to uniquely identify work orders in ~2006. Each work order was printed and clipped to one of the boards that left HQ with a team of field techs each day. The documents were a single page for one-time use. We didn't all have mobile phones.

The document contained a task and optional trouble report for a scheduled job, a travel map, network address information, compass bearings to orient the nearest four wireless access points, and provided a section for field notes.

If you have been on the receiving end of a paper stream like this you may be familiar with the vandersnack. A vandersnack is trail mix, juice, water, take-out ... any kind of grindage like snacks, suppers, ice cream, BBQ - scoffed in a work van. When the paper goes to the land of the vandersnack, sometimes it's better it doesn't come back. Soldering in the van chars the paper up a little bit and they get walked on. Pocketed, all the time. Teeth, yep. Some have chunks ripped out. There may be different jobs written on the back!

cjw6k: Boss, I jumped off the ladder over a fence and couldn't see the bottom in the long grass in mid-air. I put my hands out to balance the landing but that was a barbed-wire fence.
boss: No stitches?
cjw6k showing a hand with a patch of duct tape: Nope.

On return to HQ a field tech would open up the OST website, and add reasonably legible notes about what went on out there, aided by any chicken-scratched paper scraps of the day. The tech typed in the identifier to cue the on-screen form, 2/3 filled out. These were work orders; organized documents. Every one a unique job e.g. 10-120-405.

While working in the field, there were inevitable telephone calls to HQ. Things like timing updates to coordinate customer expectations, but then also the hard cases. Troubleshooting. I was usually on the office end of these! Apt to be an arduous journey into the unknown without a solid authoritative reference to the last-measured field conditions and as-built sources, it was imperative that the technology be leveraged to expedite a resolution by SMEs, fast. Time is money and money is time. When a conversation may start with 'what's the work order number?' and the answer is nn nnn nnn, that's very good. We have communicated of the subject issue about the subject: the last two digits of the year; day of the year; and the time of day in the GMT timezone ascribing the incident within the context of all events that were unfolding on the network at that time, AND provided a unique identifier. It can go to resolution very fast!

If you are paying quite close attention, you'll know the .beat represents one minute twenty six seconds, furthermore, that it is not good to keep things uniquely identified. That worry doesn't apply on my blog here, as they aren't unique identifiers but are being used for their time-describing quality only. Where the uniqueness does matter, we may suffix the identifier with a letter of the alphabet, a through z. These are very easy to speak on the telephone while avoiding number recall fatigue. Where it must be even more unique, a second letter a through z may be appended. These extra 676 permutations of aa through zz, provide coverage for documents originating ten-per-second sustained for one minute twenty six seconds. This, in context, would represent more than sufficient volume to declare a major outage, get onto returning voicemails, and to let everyone know: don't worry about making work orders for awhile.

An unexpected benefit of the numbering was that letters in a work order number were a canary in a coal mine for systemic error conditions evident in network weather patterns (logs++). You didn't need to be an expert to see something was going on, right away. The second work order in any one 1m 26s interval would have a letter on the end and someone's gonna say what's up to somebody. The fail-scale could move but we kept it in the good numbers üëç so I don't know what that looks like so much to see it say e.g. 12-345-678-fz [ed. blech].

Bonus: I recall that typing in the leading year was optional so 6 digits was all you needed most of the year, e.g. 222-492 was forwarded automatically to 22-222-492. I expect the dash was optional too.

Aside: The scenario played out was a real event of my life. I did not dirty up the work order that time, but rather had to leave the job to go to HQ/hospital because the safety-sense of a colleague called it. Either at that time or previously, I had received a tetanus vaccination and the record, a wallet-sized card, I had with me until the ten years transpired. There were no stitches ... I'm looking at the teensy little scar. There was some fatty tissue that had been hooked out by a barb. It squooshed right back in there. I am a MacGuyver of field dressing, shoulda stayed.

content.html:
I added prismjs. Must say, it makes me want to bundle up some script with npm like, right now.

Prismjs should make the boring code samples I publish, look a bit better, and be much easier to read and understand. We are spoiled by modern IDEs, but it's much better.

Here's a PHP example, setting up a tiny CLI script: 
#!/usr/bin/env php
<?php

use Amph\Console;
use Dice\Dice;

require_once __DIR__ . '/../vendor/autoload.php';

/** @var Dice $di */
$di = include __DIR__ . '/../core/bootstrap/ioc.php';

/** @var Console $amph */
$amph = $di->create('$amphCli');

exit($amph->run($argv));

I may come back to this later to tweak the theme a little. And there's still the whole dark mode site of things. It's on the way.
I disabled the scripts that push data up for the removed now-gaming and now-playing sections of the homepage. I also disabled micropub posting of listens.
